docs.lead_paragraph: The teams in poor countries that will be created by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation could also possibly spot emerging epidemics.

headline.main: Gates Foundation Plans Teams to Determine Causes of Child Mortality
headline.print_headline: Gates to Fund Child Mortality Initiative

docs.abstract: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation will make initial donation of $75 million to establish network of disease-surveillance teams, initially in six countries, that will seek causes of child mortality in impoverished regions and also spot emerging epidemics; member organizations will include Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and Emory University's Global Health Institute.
docs.snippet: The teams in poor countries that will be created by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation could also possibly spot emerging epidemics.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Prick a finger and have the blood checked for parasites — by smartphone? Scientists are turning phones into microscopes and other medical tools that could help fight diseases in remote parts of the world.

headline.main: Using a Smartphone Microscope to Detect Parasites in Blood

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Rich, a molecular biologist, spent nearly 60 years investigating DNA and RNA and helping puzzle out the structure of collagen.

headline.main: Alexander Rich Dies at 90; Confirmed DNA’s Double Helix
headline.print_headline: Alexander Rich Dies at 90; Confirmed Double Helix

docs.abstract: Alexander Rich, molecular biologist who produced first image of spiral DNA structure, dies at age 90.
docs.snippet: Dr. Rich, a molecular biologist, spent nearly 60 years investigating DNA and RNA and helping puzzle out the structure of collagen.

docs.lead_paragraph: An avian virus related to one that has killed 440 people in Asia is cutting through the Midwest. But experts say the risk to humans is low.

headline.main: A Flu Epidemic That Threatens Birds, Not Humans

docs.abstract: Midwestern poultry farms are being swept by avian influenza, with more than 20 million chickens and other birds already dead or culled in effort to stop spread of illness; health officials are preparing for possibility that latest avian flu virus, which is related to Asian H5N1 flu virus that has killed 440 people in Asia, could spread to humans; experts caution that risk to humans is low but are taking threat seriously and encouraging preparations.
docs.snippet: An avian virus related to one that has killed 440 people in Asia is cutting through the Midwest. But experts say the risk to humans is low.

docs.lead_paragraph: The index, which compares the world’s 25 most populous countries by how big a problem they have with three types of worms, had some surprises.

headline.main: Tracking Worms Troubles to Monitor a Country’s Health

docs.abstract: Study published in journal PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases highlights index created by scientists that ranks 25 most populous countries by severity of their health problems related to three types of worms; those nations are then compared against United Nations human development index; findings verify that poorest nations have widespread infestations.
docs.snippet: The index, which compares the world’s 25 most populous countries by how big a problem they have with three types of worms, had some surprises.
